title: Ezekiel Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 6.

questions.question: To whom did the word of the LORD come in Ezekiel 6:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:1 states that the word of the LORD came unto Ezekiel.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 6:2, where is Ezekiel told to set his face towards?
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:2 instructs Ezekiel to set his face toward the mountains of Israel.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6:3, what will God bring upon the mountains, hills, rivers, and valleys?
questions.correctAnswer: A sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:3 declares that God will bring a sword upon the mountains, hills, rivers, and valleys.

questions.question: What will happen to the altars and images according to Ezekiel 6:4?
options: Altars will be desolate and images broken
Altars will be blessed and images made whole
Altars will be burned but images preserved
Altars will be moved and images hidden
questions.correctAnswer: Altars will be desolate and images broken
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:4 says the altars shall be desolate and images shall be broken.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 6:5: 'And I will lay the dead carcases of the children of Israel before their ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: idols
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:5 states that dead carcasses will be laid before their idols.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6:6, what will happen to the cities and high places?
options: Cities will be laid waste and high places desolate
Cities will flourish and high places be built
Cities will be protected and high places blessed
Cities will be moved and high places hidden
questions.correctAnswer: Cities will be laid waste and high places desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:6 explains the cities shall be laid waste and high places desolate.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 6:7 says that the slain shall fall in the midst of the people and they shall know that God is the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:7 affirms that the slain shall fall in the midst and people shall know the LORD.

questions.question: What does God say He will leave according to Ezekiel 6:8?
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:8 states God will leave a remnant to escape the sword.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6:9, what will those who escape remember among the nations?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:9 says the escaped will remember the LORD among the nations.

questions.question: What three calamities are mentioned in Ezekiel 6:11 that will cause the house of Israel to fall?
questions.correctAnswer: Sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:11 lists sword, famine, and pestilence as causes of their fall.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 6:12 mentions that those who are far off shall die by famine.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:12 says those far off shall die of pestilence, not famine.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 6:13, where will the slain men be found?
options: Among their idols round about their altars
In the temple of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Among their idols round about their altars
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:13 states the slain will be among their idols round about their altars.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 6:14 says God will make the land more desolate than the wilderness toward Diblath.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:14 says God will make the land desolate more than the wilderness toward Diblath.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6:10, what will the people know about the LORD?
options: That He has not said in vain that He would do this evil
That He will forgive their sins
That He will send a savior
questions.correctAnswer: That He has not said in vain that He would do this evil
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:10 states they shall know the LORD has not said in vain that He would do this evil.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 6:3: 'Behold, I, even I, will bring a ______ upon you, and I will destroy your high places.'
questions.correctAnswer: sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:3 says God will bring a sword upon them and destroy their high places.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by the consequences of unfaithfulness to God. Based on Ezekiel 6, what biblical truth would you share about God's purpose in discipline?
options: God allows suffering to bring recognition that He is the LORD
God punishes without any purpose or hope
God ignores the sins of His people
God rewards sin with immediate blessings
questions.correctAnswer: God allows suffering to bring recognition that He is the LORD
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:7, 6:10, and 6:13 show that the judgment and suffering serve to make the people know that the LORD is God and that His words are true.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 6 teach us about faithfulness and its impact on future generations?
options: A remnant will escape judgment to remember God among the nations
All will be destroyed without exception
God forgets those who turn away
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant will escape judgment to remember God among the nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:8-9 explains that God will leave a remnant that will survive and remember Him, showing God's ongoing faithfulness and hope for restoration.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their integrity at work. Based on Ezekiel 6, what principle about obedience to God's Word can encourage them?
options: Obedience to God's Word is essential, or consequences will follow
Integrity is optional in difficult times
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's Word is essential, or consequences will follow
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:3-6 highlights that disobedience leads to destruction of idols and altars, symbolizing the consequences of unfaithfulness, emphasizing the importance of obedience.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 6 illustrate the importance of repentance and humility?
options: Those who acknowledge their sins will loathe themselves and turn back to God
Pride is encouraged as a virtue
Repentance is unnecessary for God's favor
Sins will be ignored if hidden
questions.correctAnswer: Those who acknowledge their sins will loathe themselves and turn back to God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:9 explains that the remnant will loathe themselves for their abominations and remember God, showing that humility and repentance are vital for restoration.

questions.question: A church member is struggling with forgiveness after being hurt. What does Ezekiel 6 teach about God's justice that can help them trust His timing?
options: God will accomplish His judgment fully, bringing justice in His time
questions.correctAnswer: God will accomplish His judgment fully, bringing justice in His time
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:11-12 shows that God will execute His fury by sword, famine, and pestilence, demonstrating His justice will be accomplished, encouraging trust in His righteous timing.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 6 encourage believers to maintain gratitude in trials?
options: By remembering God’s sovereignty even in desolation
By ignoring God’s role in trials
questions.correctAnswer: By remembering God’s sovereignty even in desolation
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:14 describes God making the land desolate but also that the people will know He is the LORD, teaching gratitude for God’s sovereign control in all circumstances.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 6 guide a believer facing temptation to worship idols or worldly things?
options: Idolatry leads to destruction and brokenness
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry leads to destruction and brokenness
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:4-6 warns that altars will be destroyed and idols broken because of Israel’s idolatry, teaching that turning away from God to idols results in ruin.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 6, God promises complete annihilation of all the people without leaving any survivors.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:8 states that God will leave a remnant to escape the sword, showing that not all will be destroyed.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 6 teaches that God's word and warnings are given in vain if not immediately fulfilled.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:10 emphasizes that God has not spoken in vain and will fulfill His words, demonstrating the certainty of His promises and warnings.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 6 says, “And the word of the LORD came unto me, saying, Son of man, set thy face toward the ______ of Israel, and prophesy against them.”
questions.correctAnswer: mountains
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:2 instructs the prophet to direct his message toward the mountains of Israel, symbolizing the whole land.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 6 teach about sharing the Gospel when believers are scattered among the nations?
options: The remnant will remember God and acknowledge their sins
They will worship foreign gods without regret
They will be silent and powerless
questions.correctAnswer: The remnant will remember God and acknowledge their sins
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:9 explains that those who escape captivity will remember God among the nations and loathe their evils, showing the power of testimony and repentance.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 6 help believers understand the role of spiritual discipline in overcoming temptation?
options: Discipline is necessary to avoid falling into idolatry and sin
Discipline is unnecessary because God will save anyway
Temptation is harmless and can be ignored
Spiritual discipline is only for religious leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Discipline is necessary to avoid falling into idolatry and sin
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:3-6 warns that idolatry leads to destruction, implying the need for spiritual discipline to remain faithful and obedient to God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with contentment during hardship. What insight does Ezekiel 6 offer about trusting God's plan in difficult times?
options: God allows hardship to make His sovereignty known
Hardship is a sign God has abandoned them
questions.correctAnswer: God allows hardship to make His sovereignty known
questions.explanation: Throughout Ezekiel 6, especially verses 7, 10, and 14, God’s judgment leads the people to know He is LORD, teaching believers to trust God's sovereign purpose even in hardship.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6, what is the expected response of believers who survive judgment regarding their past sins?
options: They will loathe themselves for their evils and turn to God
They will continue in sin without remorse
They will boast of their survival
They will blame others for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: They will loathe themselves for their evils and turn to God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:9 teaches that the survivors will loathe themselves for their sins and remember God, indicating repentance and humility.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 6 encourage practical generosity and stewardship among believers?
options: By warning that idolatry and neglect of God’s ways lead to destruction
questions.correctAnswer: By warning that idolatry and neglect of God’s ways lead to destruction
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:3-6 shows that failing to honor God properly leads to ruin, encouraging believers to live responsibly and generously under God’s commands.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 6.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 6:3, what is the primary instrument of judgment the Lord declares He will bring upon the mountains, hills, rivers, and valleys of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: A sword
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:3 states, 'Behold, I, even I, will bring a sword upon you,' indicating the sword as the instrument of divine judgment.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the fate of Israel's altars as prophesied in Ezekiel 6?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be desolate
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:4 and 6:6 emphasize that the altars will be desolate and laid waste as part of God's judgment.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6:5, what will be scattered around the altars after the judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Bones
questions.explanation: Verse 5 clearly states, 'I will scatter your bones round about your altars,' symbolizing total desecration.

questions.question: Ezekiel 6:8 speaks of a remnant that will escape the sword. What is the purpose of this remnant according to the verse?
options: To remember God among the nations
questions.correctAnswer: To remember God among the nations
questions.explanation: The remnant is left so they may remember God while scattered among the nations, as in Ezekiel 6:8.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 6:9 suggests that those who escape will be indifferent to their past sins and abominations.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:9 says the survivors will loathe themselves for their evils and abominations, showing remorse rather than indifference.

questions.question: What three calamities are mentioned in Ezekiel 6:11 as causes for the fall of the house of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Sword, famine, pestilence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:11 explicitly lists these three: 'by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence.'

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Ezekiel 6:4-6 to emphasize the total destruction of idols and altars?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The repeated structure describing destruction—altars, images, idols—demonstrates parallelism, reinforcing total desolation.

questions.question: Ezekiel 6:13 mentions several locations where slain men will be found. Which of the following is NOT listed as one of those places?
questions.correctAnswer: In the cities' public squares
questions.explanation: Verse 13 mentions hills, mountains, trees, and oaks but does not mention cities' public squares.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 6:7 function theologically in the structure of the chapter?
options: It is the hinge verse asserting that the judgment will reveal God’s sovereignty
It introduces a new prophecy unrelated to previous content
It provides historical background of Israel’s sins
It gives a promise of immediate restoration
questions.correctAnswer: It is the hinge verse asserting that the judgment will reveal God’s sovereignty
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states, 'ye shall know that I am the LORD,' functioning as a theological pivot emphasizing God's sovereignty through judgment.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'Son of man' in Ezekiel 6:2, especially in the prophetic context?
options: It emphasizes Ezekiel’s humanity and role as God’s messenger
It refers to a messianic figure
It is a royal title for the king of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes Ezekiel’s humanity and role as God’s messenger
questions.explanation: 'Son of man' underscores Ezekiel’s human status and prophetic mission, a common prophetic self-designation (Ezekiel 6:2).

questions.question: Which Old Testament location is used as a benchmark for desolation in Ezekiel 6:14?
questions.correctAnswer: Diblath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:14 compares the desolation to the wilderness toward Diblath, indicating extreme devastation.

questions.question: Ezekiel 6:12 describes different fates for those far off, near, and besieged. Which pestilence-related fate corresponds to those far off?
options: They shall die of the pestilence
They shall fall by the sword
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die of the pestilence
questions.explanation: Verse 12 specifies that those far off will die of the pestilence, contrasting with other causes for others.

questions.question: Ezekiel 6:10 emphasizes that the Lord has not spoken in vain about the coming evil. This assertion serves primarily to highlight what theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: The certainty of divine judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 10 makes clear that God's warnings are sure and the coming judgment will be fulfilled.

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'high places' and 'idols' in Ezekiel 6 reflect the broader biblical critique of Israelite religious practices?
options: They symbolize syncretistic worship condemned elsewhere in the Bible
They are metaphorical for foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: They symbolize syncretistic worship condemned elsewhere in the Bible
questions.explanation: The 'high places' and 'idols' are repeatedly condemned in biblical texts as sites of idolatry and apostasy, here highlighted in Ezekiel 6.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 6:9 uses the term 'whorish heart' metaphorically to describe Israel's unfaithfulness to God through idolatry.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The phrase 'whorish heart' in verse 9 metaphorically characterizes Israel's spiritual adultery by worshiping idols.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: To whom does God direct Ezekiel to prophesy in Ezekiel 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Mountains of Israel
questions.explanation: God commands Ezekiel to set his face toward the mountains of Israel and prophesy against them, indicating His judgment on the land and idolatry there (Ezekiel 6:2). This reflects God's direct address to the covenant people in their land, consistent with His dealings in Deuteronomy 32:22 and Isaiah 2:3-4 where mountains symbolize God's people and His judgment.

questions.question: What will God bring upon the mountains, hills, rivers, and valleys according to Ezekiel 6?
questions.correctAnswer: A sword
questions.explanation: God declares He will bring a sword upon the mountains and destroy their high places (Ezekiel 6:3), symbolizing divine judgment through warfare and destruction. This is consistent with other biblical uses of 'sword' as God's instrument of judgment (Genesis 3:24; Revelation 19:15).

questions.question: What will happen to the altars and images of Israel's idolatry as described in Ezekiel 6?
options: They shall be desolate and broken
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be desolate and broken
questions.explanation: God promises the altars will be desolate and images broken (Ezekiel 6:4), an expression of judgment against idolatry. This demonstrates God's holiness and intolerance of false worship, paralleling Leviticus 26:30 and Jeremiah 2:27 where idolatrous objects are destroyed.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6, what will be scattered around the altars?
questions.correctAnswer: Bones
questions.explanation: God states He will scatter the bones of the slain around the altars (Ezekiel 6:5), signifying the consequence of their sin and idolatry. This vivid imagery recalls Deuteronomy 28:26 and Psalm 79:2 where desecration of sacred places represents divine judgment.

questions.question: What is the purpose of making the cities and high places desolate in Ezekiel 6?
options: To abolish idols and their works
To prepare a place for a new temple
To make room for foreign nations
To start a festival of repentance
questions.correctAnswer: To abolish idols and their works
questions.explanation: The desolation aims to abolish idols and their works (Ezekiel 6:6), emphasizing God's desire to purify worship and demonstrate His sovereignty. This aligns with Isaiah 42:8 and Psalm 115:4-8 where God demands exclusive worship and destroys idolatry.

questions.question: What will the people realize when the slain fall in their midst according to Ezekiel 6?
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD is God
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:7 states the slain shall fall in their midst and they shall know the LORD, indicating recognition of God's justice. This theme echoes throughout Scripture such as in Exodus 14:31 and Romans 1:20 where God's acts lead to acknowledgment of His sovereignty.

questions.question: What does God say about a remnant in Ezekiel 6?
options: A remnant will escape the sword among the nations
No one will survive the judgment
The remnant will rebuild the idols
questions.correctAnswer: A remnant will escape the sword among the nations
questions.explanation: God promises to leave a remnant to escape the sword among the nations (Ezekiel 6:8), showing His mercy and faithfulness to His covenant. This concept of a remnant is foundational in biblical theology (Isaiah 10:20-22, Romans 11:5, Zephaniah 3:13, and Revelation 12:17).

questions.question: What causes God to be 'broken' with the people according to Ezekiel 6?
options: Their whorish heart and eyes going after idols
Their refusal to build the temple
Their failure to keep the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Their whorish heart and eyes going after idols
questions.explanation: God is grieved because of their unfaithful hearts and eyes that go after idols (Ezekiel 6:9). This metaphor of spiritual adultery highlights human sinfulness and God's righteous jealousy, consistent with Hosea 11:8, Jeremiah 3:6-10, and James 4:4.

questions.question: What is the consequence mentioned for those who are far off, near, and besieged in Ezekiel 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Pestilence, sword, and famine respectively
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:12 explains that the far off shall die by pestilence, the near by sword, and the besieged by famine—illustrating comprehensive divine judgment. This triad of judgments appears in Leviticus 26:25-26 and Jeremiah 24:10, reflecting God's justice on sin.

questions.question: What locations are specified where slain men will be found according to Ezekiel 6?
options: Among idols, altars, high hills, mountaintops, green trees, and thick oaks
questions.correctAnswer: Among idols, altars, high hills, mountaintops, green trees, and thick oaks
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:13 lists specific places where the slain will be found, emphasizing the extent of judgment on idolatrous worship sites. This recalls practices condemned in Deuteronomy 12:2-3 and Jeremiah 10:3-5, showing God's rejection of false worship.

questions.question: How does God describe the land after His judgment in Ezekiel 6?
options: More desolate than the wilderness toward Diblath
A land flowing with milk and honey
A land filled with peace and justice
questions.correctAnswer: More desolate than the wilderness toward Diblath
questions.explanation: God says He will make the land desolate more than the wilderness toward Diblath (Ezekiel 6:14), symbolizing the severity of judgment. This imagery aligns with Jeremiah 9:11 and Isaiah 34:11 where desolation signifies divine punishment.

questions.question: What does the command to 'smite with thine hand, and stamp with thy foot' in Ezekiel 6:11 symbolize?
options: An expression of lament over Israel’s abominations
questions.correctAnswer: An expression of lament over Israel’s abominations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:11 commands symbolic acts of mourning to express sorrow over Israel’s evil abominations, consistent with Old Testament lament traditions (Jeremiah 6:24; 2 Samuel 1:20; Hosea 2:7; Lamentations 2:11).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 6, what will those who escape among the nations do?
options: Remember God and loathe themselves for their abominations
Forget the LORD and embrace idols
questions.correctAnswer: Remember God and loathe themselves for their abominations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:9 teaches the escaped remnant will remember God and loathe themselves for their sins, a key theme of repentance and restoration seen in 2 Chronicles 7:14, Joel 2:12-13, Jonah 3:10, and Acts 3:19.

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose of the judgments described in Ezekiel 6?
options: That the people may know that I am the LORD
To punish the innocent with the guilty
questions.correctAnswer: That the people may know that I am the LORD
questions.explanation: Repeatedly, Ezekiel 6 emphasizes that judgment's purpose is to make the people acknowledge God's sovereignty (Ezekiel 6:7, 10, 13, 14). This aligns with Exodus 9:16, Isaiah 43:10, and Romans 11:36 where God's glory and recognition are the ultimate aims.

questions.question: Which of the following correctly summarizes the modes of divine judgment in Ezekiel 6?
questions.correctAnswer: Sword, famine, and pestilence
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 6:11-12 describes the judgment as falling by sword, famine, and pestilence, illustrating comprehensive consequences for sin, consistent with Leviticus 26:25-26 and Revelation 6:8 where these judgments are instruments of God's wrath.
